citation.article-title: Isolation of legionellae from oxidation ponds and fishponds in Israel and description of Legionella israelensis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Legionella israelensis sp. nov.
Legionella israelensis (is. ra. el. en'sis. N.L. fem. adj. israelensis coming from Israel)
Legionella israelensis is a gram-negative, oxidase-negative, motile rod or coccobaccillus.

It has the following characteristics that are typical of members of the genus Legionella: growth on BCYE agar but not on media lacking cysteine; nitrate negative; urease negative; nonfermentative, catalase positive; predominantly branched-chained cellular fatty acids; major amounts of ubiquinones with more than 10 isoprene units in the side chains.

Other biochemical reactions include lack of bluish white or red autofluorescence, absence of a brown pigment on tyrosine-containing media, weak gelatinase activity, and a negative hippurate hydrolysis reaction (Table 1). L. israelensis is the 23rd described Legionella species.
The three known strains were isolated from an oxidation pond in Gaash, Israel, in 1984.
The guanine-plus-cystosine content of DNAs from the three strains is 40.9 mol%.
